text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
ALITHIA
- Confusion and political exploitation follows US proposal on ban on Greek airforce flights over Cyprus.
- Thousands of pounds went to Astra radio from co-ops.
- The Archbishop wanted 35 million pounds in cash to sell his stake in Vassiliko cement, says businessman.
CYPRUS MAIL
- Probe into charges of co-op funding for radio station is ordered.
- UN envoy backs US proposal to halt military flights.
- Pilots union says it will stand by its grounded member.
- Vote to raise defence levy will be adressed after a review of defence spending by the National Council.
HARAVGHI
- The government tries to cover up its blunder of publicly stating it accepted a ban in Greek flights for eight months.
- The new five-year government spending plan will be debated at the National Council.
- Labour relations at Cyprus Airways to be debated in parliament on December 13.
PHILELEPHTHEROS
- The US will push for acceptance of a moratorium again early next year as part of a comprehensive proposal for the Cyprus problem.
- The Central Bank holds the key to Italcementi ITAI.MA raising its stake in Vassiliko to 33 percent from 20 percent.
SIMERINI
- US blackmail. An initiative on the Cyprus problem is conditional to the acceptance of a moratorium on Greek flights.
- Democratic Party leader Yiannakis Matsis is recovering after a quadruple by-pass operation
